00001 #import <Cocoa/Cocoa.h>
00002 
00003 
00004 @interface NSData (Crypt)
00005 
00006 // Utility method for generating keys from string passwords
00007 + (NSData*)dataKeyByteCount:(int)nKeyBytes
00008                          from7BitString:(NSString*)password ;
00009         // nKeyBytes may be of
00010         // any length, although if you believe the fiction that 
00011         // making it incredibly easy for the U.S. government to eavesdrop
00012         // is somehow protecting the world from terrorists, I believe USA
00013         // citizens are supposed to limit nKeyBytes to maximum 7 (56 bits)
00014         // or something stupid like that, in any exported product.
00015         
00016         // Password will be converted to a null-terminated UTF8 string and 
00017         // the most significant bit of each byte will be ignored.
00018         // Therefore, if password is all 127-bit low ASCII, the number of
00019         // characters required is ceil(nKeyBytes/7).
00020         
00021         // Because the null-termination is detected, the NUL character
00022         // (Unicode U+0000) is not allowed in the password.  (According to
00023         // Wikipedia, NUL is the only UTF8 sequence which includes the
00024         // byte 0x00.)
00025         
00026         // To determine the number of bytes in a password with non-ASCII
00027         // characters, you may use -[NSString lengthOfBytesUsingEncoding:]
00028         // with argument NSUTF8StringEncoding (requires Mac OS 10.4 or later).
00029         
00030 // Since RC4 is a symmetric stream encryption, the same method
00031 // is used for encrypting and decrypting.
00032 - (NSData*)cryptRC4WithKeyData:(NSData*)keyData ;       
00033         // Data returned will be same byte count (-length) as receiver. 
00034 
00035 @end
